 3 

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
equity investment of up to US$25 million equivalent in China Gas Holdings Limited (CGH); (ii) a 
proposed loan of up to US$50 million equivalent, of which up to 50% will be in US dollars and 
the balance in CNY; and (iii) a proposed loan under the complementary financing scheme of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  of  up  to  US$75  million  for  the  Municipal  Gas  Infrastructure 
Development Project. 

II. 

BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 

 

 
2. 
The  extensive  use  of  coal  in  the  PRC  has  led  to  serious  local,  regional,  and  global 
environmental problems, such as severe air pollution, acid rain, and greenhouse gas emissions. 
A report released in 1998 by the World Health Organization notes that of the 10 most polluted 
cities in the world, seven are in the PRC. Sulfur dioxide and particulates produced through coal 
combustion are two major air pollutants, resulting in the formation of acid rain, which now falls 
on about 30% of the PRC's total landmass. Industrial boilers and furnaces consume almost half 
of the PRC's coal and are the largest single point sources of urban air pollution.  
 
3. 
To  minimize  environmental  degradation,  the  Government  is  working  to  reduce  coal 
consumption  and  increase  usage  of  cleaner  fuels  such  as  natural  gas,  which  currently 
represents  less  than  3%  of  the  energy  mix  in  the  country.  While  the  Government  has 
restructured upstream oil- and gas-producing companies, the lag of reforms in the downstream 
sector  continues  to  be  a  bottleneck  to  greater  expansion  of  natural  gas  distribution  services. 
Local  gas  distribution  companies,  which  would  play  a  key  role  in  a  competitive  gas  market, 
remained controlled by the municipal government  or state-owned enterprises. To alleviate this 
bottleneck, the Government recently stepped up efforts to encourage private sector participation 
in the downstream gas distribution market by relaxing policy constraints on foreign ownership in 
municipal distribution companies.  
 
4. 
The core business of CGH is twofold: (i) the investment, operation, and management of 
municipal  natural  gas  pipeline  infrastructure;  and  (ii)  the  sale  and  distribution  of  piped  and 
compressed  natural  gas  in  municipalities  in  the PRC.  As  of March  2006,  CGH  had  developed 
and  was  operating  48  municipal  natural  gas  distribution  companies  across  eleven  provinces 
(autonomous  regions  and  directly-administered  cities),  including  Anhui,  Guangdong,  Guangxi, 
Hebei,  Hubei,  Hunan,  Jiangsu,  Liaoning,  Shaanxi,  Zhejiang  provinces,  and  Chongqing. 
Although  more  than  800,000  households  are  currently  being  connected  and  served  by  CGH, 
CGH’s  total  customer  base  is  estimated  to  exceed  4  million,  five  times  the  number  of 
households currently connected. To meet the growing demand for natural gas in the PRC, CGH 
has to carry out massive capital investments in the next several years.   
 
A. 
 

The Natural Gas Sector  

Demand and Supply 

1. 
 
5. 
Historically, natural gas has constituted a small proportion of the overall energy balance 
in  the  PRC.  Natural  gas  utilization  was  heavily  concentrated  in  fertilizer  production  to  support 
agricultural production, with little or no natural gas utilized for power generation. Consequently, 
natural  gas  demand  between  1975  and  1990  remained  relatively  stable.  Demand  growth  has 
accelerated  since  1999,  exceeding  10%  annually,  except  in  2002,  following  rapid  economic 
expansion. Natural gas consumption increased by 1.7 times in the 1990s as the economy grew. 

  

4

Consumption reached approximately 47 billion cubic meters (bcm) per annum by 2005, and is 
estimated  to  more  than  double  by  2010.  The  Energy  Research  Institute  of  the  National 
Development  and  Reform  Commission  estimates  that  natural  gas  demand  in  the  PRC  will  be 
approximately  120  bcm  in  2010  and  200  bcm  in  2020,  or  2.5  and  4.2  times  the  2005 
consumption.  
 
6. 
Total domestic natural gas supply is projected to be approximately 80 bcm in 2010 and 
110 bcm per annum in 2020. This indicates a growth rate of 7.5%, while the annual growth rate 
for natural gas demand is estimated to be 10.8% for the same period. The demand and supply 
gap  is  expected  to  be  met  by  imports,  which  will  be  achieved  via  international  pipelines  and 
liquefied natural gas.  
 
By the end of 2000, the total length of the urban gas distribution pipeline was 89,458 km. 
7. 
It  comprised  33,655  km  for  natural  gas,  48,384  km  for  coal  gas,  and  7,419  km  for  liquefied 
petroleum gas. According to the Ministry of Construction, the gas distribution subsector supplied 
8.2  bcm  of natural  gas,  15.2  bcm  of  manufactured  coal gas,  and  10.5 million  tons of  liquefied 
petroleum  gas  in  2000  when  only  about  15  large  cities  were  supplied  with  natural  gas.  The 
number of cities using natural gas increased to over 140 in 2005 and is expected to increase to 
270  by  2010.  Municipal  natural  gas  distribution  will  consume  approximately  40  bcm  of  natural 
gas,  representing  about  35%  of  the  total  natural  gas  consumption  in  the  PRC.  Downstream 
development  of  natural  gas  markets  is  estimated  to  require  significant  capital  investment: 
CNY74.8  billion  (US$9.3  billion)  during  2005–2010.  The  natural  gas  sector  is  described  in 
Appendix 1. 

Sector Policies and Regulations 

 
2. 
 
8. 
The  PRC’s  natural  gas  industry  was  vertically  integrated  under  government  mandate 
until  the  late  1990s,  with  state-owned  enterprises  responsible  for  exploration,  production, 
transportation,  and  marketing  activities.  The  industry  was  governed  by  rationing,  price  floors, 
and  ceilings,  which  were  arguably  not  reflective  of  true  production  capability.  Recently,  the 
Government has taken steps to reform and liberalize the gas market; key among these include 
(i) lifting  restrictions  on  natural  gas  usage  for  the  fertilizer  subsector  and  accelerating  the 
penetration  of  natural  gas  into  both  the  power  generation  and  residential  subsectors,  and  (ii) 
opening up the downstream gas market to foreign and private investors. 
 
9. 
Promotion  of  natural  gas  usage  can  be  attributed  to  the  Government’s  focus  on  (i) 
economic  development,  (ii)  energy  security,  and  (iii)  environmental  protection.  The  11th  Five-
Year  Plan  (2006–2010),  in  relation  to  the  energy  industry,  emphasizes  the  importance  of  a 
diversified energy base to ensure optimization of the energy mix and obtaining as much energy 
security as possible for the PRC. The abundance of domestic natural gas reserves is seen as a 
great opportunity to obtain some flexibility in its dependency on external sources of energy.  
 
10. 
To encourage the increased use of natural gas in the overall energy mix, the expansion 
of natural gas exploration and development of the transportation network are indispensable to 
improve access to natural gas. To increase the supply, encouraging regulations are in place for 
(i)  the  construction  of  the  natural  gas  trunk  pipe  network  and  supporting  facilities;  and  (ii)  the 
relaxation  and  diversification  of  downstream  distribution  network  ownership,  focusing  in 
particular on private sector ownership. This will also be in line with the national policy to develop 
the western part of the PRC, which has natural gas reserves to drive forward the much-needed 
economic development of the region.  
 

 5 

1. 

Country Strategy 

Asian Development Bank Operations 

 
B. 
 
 
 
The  ADB  country  strategy  for  the  PRC 1   is  based  on  four  development  objectives: 
11. 
(i) promotion  of  equitable  and  inclusive  growth,  (ii)  development  of  better  and  more  efficient 
markets,  (iii)  environment  improvements,  and  (iv)  promotion  of  regional  cooperation.  This  is 
consistent  with  priorities  highlighted  in  the  ADB  Medium-Term  Strategy  II  (2006–2008), 
including  catalyzing  investment  to  improve  the  investment  climate,  expanding  private  sector 
operations,  and  managing  the  environment.  ADB’s  assistance  focuses  on  reducing  the 
inequality  between  the  coastal  and  interior  provinces,  and  the  income  gap  between  the  urban 
and rural populations. The Government accords high priority to expediting the PRC’s transition 
to  a  market  economy  as  the  basis for  growth  and  job  creation,  which  require  better  and  more 
efficient markets for the private sector.  
 
To  support  Government  initiatives  to  employ  the  private  sector  as  the  driving  force  for 
12. 
the country’s long-term economic growth and job creation, ADB plans to substantially increase 
its private sector operations in the PRC focusing on the infrastructure and energy sectors, the 
financial  sector,  and  environmental  improvements.  In  the  infrastructure  and  energy  sectors, 
ADB  prioritizes  pioneering  projects  with  innovative  contractual  and  financial  structuring  to 
encourage private sector participation, enhance management expertise, and improve corporate 
governance.  
 
 

2. 
 
13. 
ADB’s  energy  sector  strategy  supports  the  following  operational  priorities  (i)  poverty 
reduction by, among other ways, creating energy infrastructure for sustainable economic growth 
and increasing the poor’s access to energy, particularly in rural areas; (ii) promotion of private 
sector involvement by restructuring the energy sector, and creating an enabling environment for 
the  private  sector;  (iii)  addressing  regional  and  global  environment  impacts  by  supporting 
measures to address acid rain problems and use of clean energy; and (iv) promotion of regional 
cooperation. 
 

Energy Sector Strategy 

III. 

THE PROJECT 

ADB Project 

 
A. 
 
14. 
The  Project,  which  allows  for  both  loan  and  equity  participation  by  ADB,  will  support 
CGH’s investment plan to fund a series of new natural gas distribution infrastructure projects in 
municipalities.  The  Project  aims  to  develop  natural  gas  distribution  infrastructure  and  address 
financial  constraints  faced  by  municipalities,  two  key  obstacles  to  natural  gas  market 
development in the PRC. 
 
B. 
 
15. 
residential, industrial, and commercial customers in municipalities.  
 

Established in 1995, CGH is a downstream natural gas distribution company, supplying 

China Gas Holdings Limited  

                                                 
1 ADB. 2005. Country Strategy and Program Update (2006–2008): People’s Republic of China. Manila. 

  

6

1. 

Shareholders 

 
16. 
CGH  is  a  majority  publicly  owned  company  on  the  Hong  Kong  Stock  Exchange.  The 
shareholding  was  recently  expanded  to  include  Gas  Authority  of  India  Limited  and  Oman  Oil 
Company, both of which have significant experience in gas distribution and technical expertise 
in their respective countries.  

 
2. 

Operations 

 
17. 
As  of  March  2006,  CGH  has  obtained  concession  rights  for  48  piped  natural  gas 
projects.  CGH  is  serving  residential,  industrial  and  commercial  customers  in  11  provinces 
(autonomous regions and directly-administered cities),  including Anhui, Guangdong, Guangxi, 
Hebei, Hubei, Hunan, Jiangsu, Liaoning, Shaanxi, Zhejiang provinces, and Chongqing.  
 
18. 
directors, and three independent nonexecutive directors.  
 
C. 
 

CGH’s  board  comprises  11  directors:  five  executive  directors,  three  nonexecutive 

Environmental Aspects and Social Dimensions 

Environment, Safety, and Health 

implementing  well-established  mitigation  measures  prescribed 

1. 
 
19. 
The nature of municipal natural gas distribution projects entails construction of facilities 
at  the  gateway  station  and  laying  small  gas  pipes.  The  design  and  operation  of  the  gateway 
station and gas distribution system are required by laws to strictly follow safety standards and 
practices that are well established by professional institutions in the gas industry. The controlling 
authorities also periodically monitor safety aspects. The construction of facilities at the gateway 
station and pipe laying are minor civil works with minor environmental disturbances that can be 
readily  minimized  by 
in 
construction contracts. Operations of the gateway station do not create a significant amount of 
waste. Only a small volume of natural gas is occasionally vented and flared for a short duration 
during  routine  maintenance  of  valves,  filters,  and  meters.  The  flaring  of  this  small  volume  of 
natural gas over a short period is unlikely to have significant impacts on ambient air quality.  
 
20. 
CGH  has  a  corporate  policy  on  health,  safety,  and  environment.  It  does  not  have  an 
explicit  social  policy  since  its  downstream  natural  gas  business  does  not  relate  to  any 
outstanding  social  issues.  CGH  abides  by  national  and  provincial  environmental  laws.  It  duly 
conducts  environmental  impact  assessments  for  all  of  its  projects  and  applies  for  all  permits 
required in implementing the projects and operating project facilities. 
 
21. 
The  Project  is  classified  as  environment  category  FI.  To  comply  with  ADB  safeguards, 
including 
CGH  will  set  up  an  environmental  management  system 
environmental assessment and review procedures for potential investments that are acceptable 
to  ADB.  ADB’s  environmental  guidelines  and  policies  and  the  PRC’s  environmental  laws  and 
regulations will be complied with, and implementation of environmental mitigation measures will 
in  collaboration  with  municipal  environmental  protection  bureaus.  Such 
be  monitored 
environmental  mitigation  measures  will  be 
reports  on  project 
implementation  and  annual  reports  on  environmental  monitoring.  CGH  will  confirm  to  ADB 
periodically its compliance with environmental requirements of ADB and the PRC, and report to 
ADB.  
 

for  new  projects, 

in  progress 

included 

2. 

Resettlement 

 7 

 
22. 
The  Project  is  classified  as  involuntary  resettlement  category  B/C  and  indigenous 
peoples  category  C.  For  downstream  natural  gas  distribution  sector  projects,  land  acquisition 
and  relocation  of  inhabitants  are  limited  and  if  needed,  are  carried  out  by  the  municipal 
governments before the concessions are open for competition. CGH thus has a limited role in 
land  acquisition  and  relocation.  For  new  concessions,  CGH  will  undertake  due  diligence  to 
ensure no acquisition of rights to land or displacement of people or enterprises. In the event of 
involuntary  resettlement  as  a  result  of  land  acquisition  by  project  companies,  CGH,  together 
with  the  relevant  joint  venture,  will  ensure  that  all  acquisition  and  resettlement  activities  are 
undertaken  in  accordance  with  the  requirements  of  ADB’s  policy  on  involuntary  resettlement2 
and the agreed resettlement framework.  
 

3. 

Development Impact 

 
23. 
The Project is designed to promote economic growth and environmental improvement by 
increasing  the  supply  of  clean  energy  and  financing  to  municipalities.  Specifically,  the  Project 
will  (i)  prevent  further  environmental  degradation  by  supporting  Government  efforts  to 
encourage  the  use  of  cleaner  fuels  in  urban  areas,  and  expand  downstream  natural  gas 
distribution  through  private  sector  participation;  (ii)  provide  flexibility  in  energy  supply  for  the 
PRC  by  taking  advantage  of  the  PRC’s  abundant  natural  gas  reserves,  which  are  largely 
underdeveloped and underutilized; (iii) help lower overall exposure to the volatility of oil prices 
and contribute to the stability of the economy; (iv) help build a nascent natural gas distribution 
market  by  providing  international  best  practices  to  the  PRC’s  downstream  distribution  market, 
thus  setting  standards  for  other  companies  to  follow  as  the  market  matures;  and  (v) 
demonstrate  social  responsibility  in  local  municipalities  through  the  enforcement  of  provincial 
policies  that  stipulate  the  preferential  supply  of  natural  gas  to  households  first,  prior  to  the 
development of the industrial customer base. 
 

4. 

Development Effectiveness 
 

24. 
ADB’s  Private  Sector  Operations  Department  and  Operations  Evaluation  Department 
are  formulating  guidelines  for  implementing  the  Good  Practice  Standards  for  Evaluation  of 
Private  Sector  Investment  Operations,  which  were  prepared  by  the  Evaluation  Cooperation 
Group of the multilateral development banks. These standards cover the roles of the Operations 
Evaluation  Department  and  Private  Sector  Operations  Department,  the  evaluation  dimensions 
for  private  sector  operations,  the  nature  of  annual  reporting,  and  dissemination  of  reports  and 
lessons. According to the standards, the three principal dimensions for private sector evaluation 
are  development  outcome  (encompassing  project  performance,  the  project’s  contribution  to 
economic  sustainability,  and  its  contribution  to  private  sector  development),  investment 
profitability  of  the  project  intervention  to  the  institution  itself  (i.e.,  specific  returns  on  the  loan, 
guarantee, or equity investment), and operational effectiveness measured and assessed on an 
overall department level. 
 
25. 
The  Project  was  assessed  and  described  from  the  perspectives  of  development 
effectiveness  and  project  framework  in  terms  of  its  specific  performance,  and  the  Project’s 
contribution  to  both  economic  sustainability  and  private  sector  development.  The  Project  is 
deemed  to  be  developmentally  effective  and  its  performance  measurable.  A  brief  summary 
discussion follows on each of these parameters. 
 

                                                 
2   ADB. 1995. Involuntary Resettlement. Manila. 

  

8

a. 

Project Performance 

 
26. 
The  Project  will  be  assessed  against  its  specific  investment  capital,  construction, 
operational  and  financial  objectives.  Essentially,  effectiveness  will  be  measured  against  how 
successfully  the  Project  attracts  private  sector  capital  (both  debt  and  equity),  how  the  Project 
secures municipal natural gas distribution concessions, how the Project develops and expands 
municipal natural gas distribution networks, and how  much natural gas the Project supplies to 
consumers  and  industries.  The  Project  will  be  also  measured  by  financial  profitability  and 
sustainability through timely debt repayment capacity and equity returns. 
 

Economic Sustainability 

The Project will be assessed, from an economic sustainability perspective, on its ability 
27. 
to develop and implement municipal natural gas distribution networks, supply municipal natural 
gas to consumers and industries, and contribute to environmental improvements and economic 
growth. Additional employment created as a result  of project implementation will be taken into 
account.  The  Project’s  successful  implementation  also  impacts  the  promotion  of  downstream 
natural gas sector reform. 
 

Private Sector Development 

28. 
The  Project  will  be  assessed  and  measured  on  how  it  contributes  to  private  sector 
development. The focus of this assessment is on the Project’s commercial and financial viability, 
and  its  demonstrative  and  catalytic  effect  on  future  private  sector  developments  in  the  natural 
gas distribution sector itself and the economy as a whole. 
 
29. 
The Project was not specifically assessed from an investment profitability point of view, 
as a profitability assessment is better gauged and measured against a portfolio of similar loans 
and equity investments. Similarly, the Project was not assessed and measured against overall 
operational effectiveness, as this is a departmental consideration.  

 
b. 
 

 
c. 
 

 
IV.  THE PROPOSED ASSISTANCE 
 

Equity Investment 

A. 
 
30. 
The proposed equity investment is to subscribe for ordinary shares in CGH at a cost of 
up  to  US$25  million.    The  proposed  ADB  equity  investment  constitutes  a  critical  and  integral 
part of ADB assistance for CGH and the Project. ADB will be entitled to nominate a person to be 
appointed as a nonexecutive director on the CGH board throughout the period that ADB holds 
the shares. 
 
B. 

Loans 
 
31. 
The  proposed  direct  loan  is  for  up  to  US$50  million  equivalent:  50%  will  be  lent  in  US 
dollars  and  the  balance  in  CNY.  A  proposed  complementary  loan  is  for  up  to  US$75  million 
under ADB’s complementary financing scheme will be lend in US dollars.  
 
C. 
 

Justification 

 ADB’s assistance for the Project is justified on the basis of its development impacts and 
32. 
demonstration effects. It supports the Government’s development plans and ADB’s operational 
strategies, and provides the value added of ADB participation in the Project: 

9 

The  Project  will  provide  access  to  a  clean,  reliable,  and  long-term  energy 
source to the people in municipalities where adequate municipal natural gas 
infrastructure is lacking and demand is currently not fully met.  

The Project will contribute to the PRC’s efforts to promote the use of natural 
gas  and  improve  the  environment.  The  Project  will  have  a  significant 
development  impact  by  helping  reduce  air  pollution  by  substituting  natural 
gas  for  coal  energy.  The  reduction  of  particulates  and  sulfur  dioxide  from 
households and  small  industries  will  have  the  most  beneficial  impact  on  the 
urban  population,  in  particular  the  urban  poor,  who  suffer  severely  from 
indoor and outdoor air pollution.  

The  Project  supports  the  Government’s  strategy  of  encouraging  private 
sector participation in the municipal natural gas distribution sector, given the 
substantial investment required in expanding the natural gas pipeline network 
and  the  limited  self-financing  capacity  of  the  municipalities.  The  Project  is 
expected  to  free  up  municipal  governments’  resources  from  investments  in 
natural gas distribution to other types of critical expenditures related to social 
concerns and health.  

The Project is in line with ADB’s country and energy sector strategies, which 
emphasize  supporting  energy  infrastructure  development  with  private  sector 
participation  and  environmentally  clean  technology.  It  also  supports  ADB’s 
thematic  priorities  of  economic  development,  private  sector  development, 
good  governance,  and  environmental  protection.  The  Project  contributes  to 
the  promotion  of  ADB’s  operational  priorities  in  the  energy  sector  by 
(a) providing  innovation  in  investment  priorities  through  funding  of  municipal 
natural  gas  distribution,  (b)  supplying  clean  energy  where  environmental 
degradation  is  serious,  and  (c)  enhancing  access  to  clean  energy  for  urban 
and peripheral residents. 

The  Project  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  private  sector  operations  in  the  PRC, 
which have focused on the infrastructure and energy sectors, financial sector, 
and  environmental  improvements.  In  the  infrastructure  and  energy  sectors, 
ADB  prioritizes  pioneering  participation,  enhancing  management  expertise, 
and  improving  corporate  governance.  This  Project  will  provide  highly  skilled 
employment and know-how transfer opportunity to the local community.  

 
(i) 

 
(ii) 

 
(iii) 

 
(iv) 

 
(v) 

 

 
D. 

Anticorruption, Combating Money Laundering and the Financing of Terrorism 

CGH  was  advised  of  ADB’s  policies  on  anticorruption 3   and  combating  of  money 
33. 
laundering  and  financing  of  terrorism. 4  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good  governance, 
accountability, and transparency, ADB will require CGH to institute, maintain, and comply with 

                                                 
3   ADB. 1998. Anticorruption. Manila. 
4   ADB. 2003. Enhancing the Asian Development Bank’s Role in Combating Money Laundering and the Financing of 

Terrorism. Manila. 

  

10

internal procedures and controls following international best practice standards for the purpose 
of  preventing  corruption  or  money  laundering  activities  or  the  financing  of  terrorism,  and 
covenant  with  ADB  to  refrain  from  engaging  in  such  activities.  The  investment  documentation 
between ADB and CGH will allow ADB to investigate any violation or potential violation of these 
undertakings. 
 

V. 

ASSURANCES 

 
A framework agreement relating to ADB’s status, privileges, and immunities with respect 
34. 
to  its  equity  investments  and  lending  operations  in  the  private  sector  is  in  effect  between  the 
Government  and  ADB.  Consistent  with  the  Agreement  Establishing  the  Asian  Development 
Bank  (the  Articles  of  Agreement),  the  Government  will  be  requested  to  confirm  that  it  has  no 
objection  to  the  proposed  assistance  to  the  Project.  No  funding  will  be  disbursed  until  ADB 
receives such confirmation. In addition, ADB will enter into suitable share subscription and loan 
documentation on terms and conditions satisfactory to ADB.  
 

VI. 

RECOMMENDATION 

I  am  satisfied  that  the  proposed  equity  investment  and  loans  would  comply  with  the 

 
35. 
Articles of Agreement of ADB, and recommend that the Board approve  
 

a proposed equity investment for an amount up to US$25,000,000 equivalent;  

a direct loan for an amount up to US$50,000,000 equivalent, of which up to 50% 
is to be lent in US dollars and the balance in CNY; and  

a  complementary 
complementary financing scheme 

for  an  amount  up 

to  US$75,000,000  under  ADB’s 

for the Municipal Natural Gas Infrastructure Development Project, and on such other terms and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in this report, and as may be 
reported to the Board. 
 

Haruhiko Kuroda

 14 
 

Appendix 1      

Background 

THE NATURAL GAS SECTOR  

1. 
The  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  is  the  world’s  second  largest  energy  producer 
and  consumer  after  the  United  States.  Coal  has  historically  been  the  fuel  of  choice,  with 
abundant reserves located throughout the country. Many power stations are coal-fired, and coal 
is used for domestic cooking and heating.  
 
In 2004, coal remained the largest source of energy, comprising approximately 66% of 
2. 
the total energy mix. Oil and petroleum products constituted 23%; other energy sources, such 
as hydro and other renewable accounting for 8%; and gas for 3%. 
 
Natural  gas  usage  in  the  PRC  is  set  to  grow  rapidly  as  natural  gas  is  (i) cleaner  than 
3. 
most fuels, (ii) economic, and (iii) domestically abundant. The introduction of natural gas into the 
power  and  nonpower  sectors  will  significantly  reduce  emissions  of  particulates,  sulfur  dioxide 
(SO2),  nitrogen  oxide  (NOx),  and  carbon  dioxide  (CO2).The  price  of  natural  gas  is  lower  than 
most other forms of fuel on a heat content-adjusted basis. For example, it is approximately 34–
88% lower than coal gas, approximately 38–52% cheaper than liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), 
and approximately 63–80% lower than electricity.  
 
4. 
The  PRC  has  abundant  natural  gas  reserves,  estimated  at  approximately  2.35  trillion 
cubic  meters  (tcm)  proven  natural  gas  reserves  in  2005. 5   The  Government  estimates  total 
reserves  of  natural  gas  at  approximately  38  tcm,  of  which  78.6%  are  onshore  and  21.4% 
offshore.  Onshore  natural  gas  reserves  are  mainly  concentrated  in  the  middle  and  western 
regions  of  the  PRC  such  as  Chongqing,  Gansu,  Sichuan,  Qinghai,  and  Xinjiang.  Offshore 
natural gas reserves are mainly concentrated near the South China Sea. Onshore domestic gas 
production  is  concentrated  in  the  western  region,  and  undertaken  by  PetroChina  and  China 
Petroleum  &  Chemical  Corporation  (Sinopec).  Offshore  production  is  undertaken  by  China 
National Offshore Oil Corporation (CNOOC).  
 
Gas Demand 

5. 
Historically, natural gas has constituted a small proportion of the overall energy balance 
in  the  PRC.  Gas  utilization  was  heavily  concentrated  in  fertilizer  production  to  support 
agricultural  production,  with  little  or  no  gas  utilized  for  power  generation.  Consequently,  gas 
demand between 1975 and 1990 remained relatively stable. Since 1990, gas demand increased 
as the economy grew. Gas consumption increased by 1.7 times in the 1990s. Demand growth 
has accelerated since 1999, exceeding 10% annually except in 2002 following rapid economic 
expansion. However, gas remains a small percentage of the energy mix. Figure A2.1 presents 
gas consumption from 1965–2005. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
                                                 
5   BP plc. 2006. BP Statistical Review of World Energy 2006. London.

6. 
The PRC’s growing economy and environmental concerns have been key drivers for the 
increasing use of gas. By 2005, gas consumption had grown to approximately 47 billion cubic 
meters (bcm) per annum; this is forecast to more than double by 2010. Demand will continue to 
grow for the foreseeable future, with estimates, by the Energy Research Institute of the National 
Development and Reform Commission, for natural gas demand to be approximately 120 bcm in 
2010 and 200 bcm in 2020, or 2.5 and 4.2 times the 2005 consumption.  
 
Forecasts  of  gas  demand  are  subject  to  a  high  degree  of  uncertainty,  as  gas 
7. 
consumption depends heavily on the successful construction of trunk pipelines, and the rate of 
gas penetration in the power and nonpower sectors, especially the rate of conversion of existing 
manufactured gas distribution and consumption facilities. However, all sources agree that strong 
growth  in  demand  will  be  felt  for  natural  gas  in  power  generation  and  residential  uses.  Figure 
A2.2 presents a breakdown of demand projections by sector prepared by PetroChina.

Appendix 1      

Gas Supply 

8. 
The  Energy  Research  Institute  of  the  National  Development  and  Reform  Commission 
projects total domestic gas supply to be approximately 80 bcm per annum in 2010 and 110 bcm 
in  2020.  This  indicates  a  growth  rate  of  7.5%,  while  the  annual  growth  rate  for  natural  gas 
demand is estimated to be 10.8% for the same period (Figure A2.3). The demand and supply 
gap  is  expected  to  be  met  by  imports,  which  will  be  achieved  via  international  pipelines  and 
liquefied natural gas (LNG).

11. 
According  to  the  Ministry  of  Construction,  the  gas  distribution  subsector  supplied  8.2 
bcm of natural gas, 15.2 bcm of manufactured coal gas, and 10.5 million tons of LPG in 2000. A 
total of 176.3 million people were supplied with gas, accounting for 84% of the country’s urban 
(or nonagricultural) population. Sixty-three percent used LPG, 13% used natural gas, and 23% 
used  coal  gas.  These  data  are  significantly  higher  than  those  provided  by  the  PRC  Gas

12. 
In 2000, only about 15 large cities and some small ones were supplied with natural gas. 
In  2005,  140  cities  were  supplied  with  natural  gas  compared  with  60  in  2003.  The  number  of 
cities  using  natural  gas  is  expected  to  increase  to  270  in  2010,  and  city  gas  distribution  will 
consume  41.4  bcm  of  natural  gas;  a  volume  that  will  represent  about  35%  of  the  total  natural 
gas consumption in the country.  
 
1
Regardless  of  the  statistics  of  the  current  penetration  rate  for  gas  usage,  the  market 
potential  for  natural  gas  in  urban  areas  remains  substantial.  Development  of  downstream 
natural  gas  markets  is  estimated  to  require  significant  capital  investment—approximately 
CNY74.8 billion (US$9.3 billion) during 2005–2010.

17. 
Polyethylene  technology  has  been  very  limited  in  the  PRC  but  is  beginning  to  be 
developed  in  areas  with  local  production  of  the  corresponding  materials.  When  new  networks

rapidly, local supply sources are being developed to meet the future demand for materials and 
other equipment.
